elements.content: Copper­(I) iodine compounds can exhibit interesting mechanochromic and thermochromic luminescent properties with important technological applications. We report the synthesis and structure determination by X-ray diffraction of a new polymeric staircase copper­(I) iodine compound catena­(bis­(μ2-iodo)-6-methylquinoline-copper­(I), [C10H9CuIN]. The structure is composed of isolated polymeric staircase chains of copper–iodine coordinated to organic ligands through Cu–N bonds. High pressure X-ray diffraction to 6.45 GPa shows that the material is soft, with a bulk modulus K 0 = 10.2(2)­GPa and a first derivative K′0 = 8.1(3), typical for organometallic compounds. The unit-cell compression is very anisotropic with the stiffest direction [302] arising from a combination of the stiff CuI ladders and the shear of the planar quinolone ligands over one another. Full structure refinements at elevated pressures show that pressures reduce the Cu···Cu distances in the compound. This effect is detected in luminescence spectra with the appearance of four sub-bands at 515, 600, 647, and 712 nm above 3.5 GPa. Red-shifts are observed, and they are tentatively associated with interactions between copper­(I) ions due to the shortening of the Cu···Cu distances induced by pressure, below twice the van der Waals limit (2.8 Å). Additionally, ab initio simulations were performed, and they confirmed the structure and the results obtained experimentally for the equation of state. The simulation allowed the band structure and the electronic density of states of this copper­(I) iodine complex to be determined. In particular, the band gap decreases slowly with pressure in a quadratic way with dE g /dP = −0.011 eV/GPa and d2 E g /dP 2 = 0.001 eV/GPa2.

We report the synthesis and structure determination by X-ray diffraction of a new polymeric staircase copper(I) iodine compound catena(bis(μ2-iodo)-6-methylquinoline-copper(I), [C10H9CuIN]. The unit-cell compression is very anisotropic with the stiffest direction [302] arising from a combination of the stiff CuI ladders and the shear of the planar quinolone ligands over one another. Additionally, ab initio simulations were performed, and they confirmed the structure and the results obtained experimentally for the equation of state. The simulation allowed the band structure and the electronic density of states of this copper(I) iodine complex to be determined. In particular, the band gap decreases slowly with pressure in a quadratic way with dE  g /dP = -0.011 eV/GPa and d2 E  g /dP 2 = 0.001 eV/GPa2.

elements.content: Synthesis and structure determination of a new copper­(I) iodine compound with 6-methylquinoline as organic ligand are presented. Structure, isothermal equation of state, and luminescence properties under pressure up to 6.45 GPa were determined. Ab initio simulations corroborate the experimental results and allow the electronic structure to be calculated.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis and structure determination of a new copper(I) iodine compound with 6-methylquinoline as organic ligand are presented. Structure, isothermal equation of state, and luminescence properties under pressure up to 6.45 GPa were determined. Ab initio simulations corroborate the experimental results and allow the electronic structure to be calculated.

elements.content: Complexes of copper­(I) iodine with organic ligands display a great variety of structural conformations such as rhomboid dimers, cubane, tetramers, zigzag, and stair step polymers, which also have rich luminescence properties with potential technological applications in photovoltaic devices, biosensors, OLEDs, solar energy conversion, photochemical catalysis, and absorption processes, among others. These luminescence properties can arise from four different mechanisms. The first is metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) in the excited state, which is sensitive to the rigidity of the ligand. The second is associated with high energy (HE) halide-to-ligand charge transfer (XLCT). The third is related to a lower energy (LE) mixed halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT), and finally, the fourth arises from cluster centered (CC) transfer. Some authors have suggested that metal–metal interactions are crucial to the emission behavior and noted that LE is displayed only by those clusters with Cu···Cu distances less than 2.8 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Complexes of copper(I) iodine with organic ligands display a great variety of structural conformations such as rhomboid dimers, cubane, tetramers, zigzag, and stair step polymers, which also have rich luminescence properties with potential technological applications in photovoltaic devices, biosensors, OLEDs, solar energy conversion, photochemical catalysis, and absorption processes, among others. These luminescence properties can arise from four different mechanisms. The first is metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) in the excited state, which is sensitive to the rigidity of the ligand. The second is associated with high energy (HE) halide-to-ligand charge transfer (XLCT). The third is related to a lower energy (LE) mixed halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT), and finally, the fourth arises from cluster centered (CC) transfer. Some authors have suggested that metal-metal interactions are crucial to the emission behavior and noted that LE is displayed only by those clusters with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances less than 2.8 Å.

elements.content: Most studies published to date have been done at ambient conditions or at low and high temperatures, but rarely under pressure. Knowing the behavior of these materials under different environmental conditions is not only essential for commercial and technological applications. The effect of high pressure on solids immersed in hydrostatic conditions also gives us information about the variation of volume and unit-cell parameters, and therefore allows the determination of their isothermal equations of state (EoS). Equations of state not only provide fundamental thermodynamic data that are required for the calculation of equilibrium phase diagrams, but also give insights into the details of interatomic interactions that are influenced by the externally applied compressive stresses and control the dynamics that lead to thermal expansion. Pressure affects the rest of the properties of solids and enables us to study how the elastic properties of the material change in response to compression and expansion. In the case of luminescence properties, it helps to determine the influence of the coordination environment and electronic structure. For copper­(I) iodine complexes, the position and relative intensity of the CC band (λmax em = 580 nm) has a particular sensitivity to temperature and pressure. Moreover, in similar complexes, the changes in the emission spectra correspond to MLCT bands (λmax em = 610 nm).

elements.content: In this paper, we present a complete experimental study of a new copper­(I) iodine complex [C10H9CuIN], including the synthesis, structure determination, luminescence properties, and their evolution under high pressure at room temperature (RT). We have also performed ab initio simulations to compare the results and study the electronic properties so that the results can be useful to future technological developments.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we present a complete experimental study of a new copper(I) iodine complex [C10H9CuIN], including the synthesis, structure determination, luminescence properties, and their evolution under high pressure at room temperature (RT). We have also performed ab initio simulations to compare the results and study the electronic properties so that the results can be useful to future technological developments.

elements.content: The compound C10H9CuIN was prepared by mixing an equimolar amount of 6-methylquinoline (0.15 g, 1.05 mmol) with CuI (0.2 g, 1.05 mmol) in a saturated solution of KI in toluene (80 mL). The mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Then, the reaction mixture was filtered off, and the solid was dissolved in acetonitrile (60 mL) to give a pale yellow solution. After 2 days, single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent in high yield.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

The compound C10H9CuIN was prepared by mixing an equimolar amount of 6-methylquinoline (0.15 g, 1.05 mmol) with CuI (0.2 g, 1.05 mmol) in a saturated solution of KI in toluene (80 mL). The mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Then, the reaction mixture was filtered off, and the solid was dissolved in acetonitrile (60 mL) to give a pale yellow solution. After 2 days, single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent in high yield.

elements.content: Found: C, 35.7; H, 2.6, N, 4.2%. Calcd for C10H9CuIN: C, 36.0; H, 2.7; N, 4.2%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3442, 2358, 2337, 1645, 1627, 1592, 1503, 1378, 1312, 1235, 1124. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6) (δ, ppm): 9.0 (s,1H), 8.3 (d, J = 8.3 Hz,1H), 8.1 (s,1H), 7.8 (s,1H), 7.6 (s,1H), 7.6 (d, J = 6.7 Hz,1H), 2.5 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6) (δ, ppm): 136.1 (2CH), 135.2 (C), 131.6 (2CH), 128.9 (2C), 126.8 (2CH), 21.0 (CH3).

All X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were made at room temperature using an Agilent SuperNOVA diffractometer equipped with an EOS detector (CCD) and Mo radiation microsource. All measurements were processed with the CrysAlisPro software. The structure of the compound was determined by a dual-space algorithm using the SHELXT program, and refinement was performed using the SHELXL program against F 2 by full-matrix least-squares refinement. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were included in the model at calculated positions, and refined with a rigid model with their U iso value to 1.2U eq of their parent atoms. The PLATON program has been used for geometric calculations.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction Measurements

All X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were made at room temperature using an Agilent SuperNOVA diffractometer equipped with an EOS detector (CCD) and Mo radiation microsource. All measurements were processed with the CrysAlisPro software. The structure of the compound was determined by a dual-space algorithm using the SHELXT program, and refinement was performed using the SHELXL program against F 2 by full-matrix least-squares refinement. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were included in the model at calculated positions, and refined with a rigid model with their U iso value to 1.2U eq of their parent atoms. The PLATON program has been used for geometric calculations.

elements.content: For high pressure measurements we have used a Diacell Bragg-S diamond anvil cell (DAC) from Almax-EasyLab, with an opening angle of 90° and anvil culets of 600 μm diameter, fitted with a stainless steel gasket containing a hole of 250 μm diameter and 70 μm depth. A methanol–ethanol–water mixture (16:4:1) was used as pressure-transmitting medium, which remains hydrostatic in the range of pressure used in our experiments in order to minimize deviatoric stresses which can cause incorrect values for the bulk modulus. The sample was placed on one of the diamonds anvils (incident side) together with a small ruby sphere as pressure sensor. The structure was refined, for each pressure, using previous results as starting point, on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares refinement using the SHELXL program. Due to limitations of the opening angle of our DAC, it is only possible to collect about 30% of the reflections present in a full data set at ambient conditions. In this situation, structure refinements were performed with isotropic displacement parameters for all atoms except for the heavy atoms (Cu and I) that were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters whenever they did not become nonpositive definite. Hydrogen atoms were included in the final procedure in the same way as for ambient conditions. No restraints were used during this process.

elements.content: Absorption spectra were recorded with a UV–vis–NIR-spectrophotometer (Cary 5000). The luminescence spectra were obtained under a 405 nm diode laser excitation and recorded using a 0.75 m single grating monochromator (Spex 750M) equipped with a cooled photomultiplier (PMT) (Hamamatsu 928P). All of the spectra have been corrected for the instrument response. Due to the limitation of the experimental setup, requiring a colinear configuration for the laser excitation and the detector, an edge long pass filter (488 nm) was used to remove the direct light of the laser exiting through the sample. This limits the starting wavelength of the spectra to 490 nm. Luminescence spectra as a function of pressure have been obtained up to 4.5 GPa. High pressure was generated with a miniature DAC, designed at the University of Paderborn (Germany), with low luminescent type II-a diamonds for optical and infrared measurements. The optical high pressure experiments were performed in sample chambers of dimensions Ø = 150 μm and h = 70 using 10 μm ruby chips as pressure sensor. Lifetime measurements have been carried out by exciting with an Optical Parametric Oscillator OPO (EKSPLA/NT342/3UVE). The emission was focused onto a 0.32 m monochromator (Jobin Yvon Triax 320) coupled with a cooled PMT (Hamamatsu 928P) and recorded and averaged using a digital storage oscilloscope (LeCroy WS424).
elements.clean_text:
Optical Measurements

Absorption spectra were recorded with a UV-vis-NIR-spectrophotometer (Cary 5000). The luminescence spectra were obtained under a 405 nm diode laser excitation and recorded using a 0.75 m single grating monochromator (Spex 750M) equipped with a cooled photomultiplier (PMT) (Hamamatsu 928P). All of the spectra have been corrected for the instrument response. Due to the limitation of the experimental setup, requiring a colinear configuration for the laser excitation and the detector, an edge long pass filter (488 nm) was used to remove the direct light of the laser exiting through the sample. This limits the starting wavelength of the spectra to 490 nm. Luminescence spectra as a function of pressure have been obtained up to 4.5 GPa. High pressure was generated with a miniature DAC, designed at the University of Paderborn (Germany), with low luminescent type II-a diamonds for optical and infrared measurements. The optical high pressure experiments were performed in sample chambers of dimensions Ø = 150 μm and h = 70 using 10 μm ruby chips as  pressure sensor. Lifetime measurements have been carried out by exciting with an Optical Parametric Oscillator OPO (EKSPLA/NT342/3UVE). The emission was focused onto a 0.32 m monochromator (Jobin Yvon Triax 320) coupled with a cooled PMT (Hamamatsu 928P) and recorded and averaged using a digital storage oscilloscope (LeCroy WS424).

elements.content: Ab initio simulations within the framework of DFT have been performed with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). For this type of compound, van der Waals interactions play an important role, and therefore, they have been taken into account with the zero damping DFT-D3 method of Grimme et al. as implemented in VASP. The projector-augmented wave scheme (PAW) was employed to take into account the full nodal character of the all-electron charge density in the core region. Because the compound contains carbon atoms, basis sets including plane waves up to an energy cutoff of 520 eV were used in order to achieve highly converged results and an accurate description of the electronic properties. The exchange-correlation energy was considered in the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzenhof (PBE) prescription. A 7 × 3 × 3 special k-points sampling scheme, which corresponds to a set of 32 k-points, was employed for the Brillouin zone (BZ) integration to obtain very well-converged energies and forces. At fixed selected volumes, the structures were fully relaxed to their optimized configuration through the calculation of the forces on atoms and the stress tensor. This allows the relaxed structures (cell parameters and atomic positions) to be obtained at the theoretical pressures defined by the calculated stress. In the optimized configurations the forces on the atoms are smaller than 0.004 eV/Å, and deviations of the stress tensor from a diagonal hydrostatic form are negligible. The set of energy (E), volume (V), and pressure (P) points provided by calculations were fitted with an EoS to obtain the equilibrium volume, the bulk modulus, and its derivative. The band structure along high symmetry directions in the BZ and the density of states (DoS) were also calculated. The application of DFT-based total-energy calculations to the study of semiconductor properties under high pressure has been reviewed, showing that the phase stability, electronic, and dynamical properties of compounds under pressure are well-described by DFT.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

 Ab initio simulations within the framework of DFT have been performed with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). For this type of compound, van der Waals interactions play an important role, and therefore, they have been taken into account with the zero damping DFT-D3 method of Grimme et al. as implemented in VASP. The projector-augmented wave scheme (PAW) was employed to take into account the full nodal character of the all-electron charge density in the core region. Because the compound contains carbon atoms, basis sets including plane waves up to an energy cutoff of 520 eV were used in order to achieve highly converged results and an accurate description of the electronic properties. The exchange-correlation energy was considered in the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzenhof (PBE) prescription. A 7 × 3 × 3 special k-points sampling scheme, which corresponds to a set of 32 k-points, was employed for the Brillouin zone (BZ) integration to obtain very well-converged energies and forces. At fixed selected volumes, the structures were fully relaxed to their optimized configuration through the calculation of the forces on atoms and the stress tensor. This allows the relaxed structures (cell parameters and atomic positions) to be obtained at the theoretical pressures defined by the calculated stress. In the optimized configurations the forces on the atoms are smaller than 0.004 eV/Å, and deviations of the stress tensor from a diagonal hydrostatic form are negligible. The set of energy (E), volume (V), and pressure (P) points provided by calculations were fitted with an EoS to obtain the equilibrium volume, the bulk modulus, and its derivative. The band structure along high symmetry directions in the BZ and the density of states (DoS) were also calculated. The application of DFT-based total-energy calculations to the study of semiconductor properties under high pressure has been reviewed, showing that the phase stability, electronic, and dynamical properties of compounds under pressure are well-described by DFT.

elements.content:
The main crystal data and structure refinement parameters at ambient conditions are reported in .

The crystal structure of complex C10H9CuIN is formed by a very simple asymmetric unit (). When it is expanded, a polymeric staircase motif of copper–iodine is generated parallel to the a-axis ().

Each copper­(I) atom is four-coordinated, to three iodine atoms and the nitrogen of the organic ligand. The shape of this coordination environment can be described by a single geometric index called τ4 that takes a value of 1.0 for a perfect tetrahedral configuration while it will be 0.0 in the case of a perfect square configuration. In the case of intermediate configurations such as trigonal pyramidal, the τ4 parameter will have a value between 0.0 and 1.0. In the complex under study, the τ4 is 0.80 indicating a distorted trigonal pyramidal configuration. The iodine atom is three-coordinated, and the quinoline ligands preserve their planarity displaying aromatic π–π stacking in the direction of propagation of the Cu–I ribbons.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

X-ray Diffraction Analysis

The main crystal data and structure refinement parameters at ambient conditions are reported in .

The crystal structure of complex C10H9CuIN is formed by a very simple asymmetric unit (). When it is expanded, a polymeric staircase motif of copper-iodine is generated parallel to the a-axis ().

Each copper(I) atom is four-coordinated, to three iodine atoms and the nitrogen of the organic ligand. The shape of this coordination environment can be described by a single geometric index called τ4 that takes a value of 1.0 for a perfect tetrahedral configuration while it will be 0.0 in the case of a perfect square configuration. In the case of intermediate configurations such as trigonal pyramidal, the τ4 parameter will have a value between 0.0 and 1.0. In the complex under study, the τ4 is 0.80 indicating a distorted trigonal pyramidal configuration. The iodine atom is three-coordinated, and the quinoline ligands preserve their planarity displaying aromatic π-π stacking in the direction of propagation of the Cu-I ribbons.

elements.content: Geometric parameters for this compound at ambient conditions are similar to the values measured in similar staircases in copper iodine structures with organic ligands contained in the CSD Database (version 5.36). We found 2.6406(6) Å for Cu–I and 2.044(3) Å for Cu–N distances, respectively, in good agreement with the values 2.66(5) and 2.04(3) Å reported in CSD. For angles, the value for I–Cu–N in our complex is 110.20(9)° while the average value obtained from CSD was 110(5)°. In the case of I–Cu–I angles, this parameter is characterized by a range from 93.02° to 119.37°. In the present compound these values are 99.81(2)° and 117.76(2)°. The shorter Cu···Cu distance is 2.8014(8) Å while the stacking distance between quinoline layers is 3.582(2) Å (centroid–centroid) indicating very weak π–π interactions. The rest of the packing interactions can be considered as being van der Waals type.
elements.clean_text: Geometric parameters for this compound at ambient conditions are similar to the values measured in similar staircases in copper iodine structures with organic ligands contained in the CSD Database (version 5.36). We found 2.6406(6) Å for Cu-I and 2.044(3) Å for Cu-N distances, respectively, in good agreement with the values 2.66(5) and 2.04(3) Å reported in CSD. For angles, the value for I-Cu-N in our complex is 110.20(9)° while the average value obtained from CSD was 110(5)°. In the case of I-Cu-I angles, this parameter is characterized by a range from 93.02° to 119.37°. In the present compound these values are 99.81(2)° and 117.76(2)°. The shorter Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is 2.8014(8) Å while the stacking distance between quinoline layers is 3.582(2) Å (centroid-centroid) indicating very weak π-π interactions. The rest of the packing interactions can be considered as being van der Waals type.

elements.content: presents the behavior of the main bond distances and angles with pressure. The evolution of these parameters shows that the main changes produce a slight adjustment of the Cu–I ladders associated with a decreasing spacing between the quinoline layers. The layers maintain their planarity and orientation, but the small displacement of the ligands over one another (b) appears to be the cause for the increase on the β angle in the unit-cell parameters with pressure. The average distortion of copper­(I) was τ4 = 0.82(2), and its tetrahedral volume decreased linearly with pressure (see Supporting Information).

EoS Analysis

Evolution of all unit-cell parameters is smooth up to the maximum pressure achieved. The c-axis is substantially softer than a- and b-axes, and the β angle is the most variable angle while the γ angle remains almost unchanged. Plots of the b, c, and V unit-cell parameters as normalized pressure (F) pressure against finite strain (f) (i.e., f-F plots, ) are straight lines with positive slopes within the uncertainties, indicating that they can be fit with third-order Birch-Murnaghan (BM) EoS.

elements.content: The f–F plot of the a unit-cell parameter is a horizontal line at higher pressures, indicating that a second-order BM EoS is appropriate to describe the data, although this plot also exhibits a curvature at low pressures indicating that the value of a 0 is not consistent with the higher pressure data. However, comparison of data collected from crystals within the DAC but without pressure fluid and data from crystals in air shows that the formal uncertainties obtained for the unit-cell parameters are underestimated, and this accounts for the observed curvature in the f–F plots.

The bulk modulus obtained for C10H9CuIN falls into the range 10–20 GPa typical for organometallic compounds while diamond has a K 0 of 440 GPa. In general, these lower values are attributable to deformability of the intermolecular interactions or voids present in the structure. Recently, Benito et al. did a study of a mechanochromic copper iodide cluster (cubane Cu–I) under hydrostatic pressure. They did not report any EoS calculations, but from Supporting Information we have done the calculations using only the data from powder X-ray diffraction to compare with our results. In this case, using the BM3 EoS, the values were 7.07(7) GPa and 10(1) for K 0 and K′0, respectively. The elastic properties are therefore similar to those of our title compound even though the compound analyzed by Benito et al. is a cubane cluster of Cu–I crystallized in a tetragonal system while we have a staircase ribbon of Cu–I crystallized in a triclinic system.

elements.content: These fits () confirm that the hydrostatic compression of this material is very anisotropic, with the c-axis being much softer than the other two unit-cell axes. However, this material is triclinic, and therefore, the compression of the unit-cell axes alone does not necessarily represent the true compressibility tensor. The true pattern of compressibility is represented by the strain ellipsoid due to compression; two of the principal axes of this ellipsoid represent the directions of minimum and maximum compression, which can rotate with respect to the unit-cell axes during compression. The Win_Strain program was used to calculate the principal strains from the measured unit-cell parameters at each pressure and the room pressure unit-cell. We used the Eulerian finite strain definition because this is the same as that used for BM EoS calculations; the orientation of the strain ellipsoid is not sensitive to the choice of strain definition. The orientation of the strain ellipsoid does not change or rotate much with pressure, and so, the ratios of compressibilities in the three principal directions are approximately constant.

elements.content: The principal axis of intermediate compression remains close to b*. Therefore, the directions of minimum and maximum compression lie close to within the (010) plane. The softest direction lies 62° from a, and 26° from c, close to the [302] direction, between the +a and +c base vectors of the unit cell. The stiffest direction is 90° from this direction and is thus close to the (2̅03) plane normal. These relative compressibilities arise in part from the large change in the β angle, which increases from 83° to 87° at the highest pressures, due in part to the displacement of the quinolone layers over one another (b). This indicates that a major mechanism of deformation is a shear of the structure in the (010) plane. This opening of the β angle contributes to a contraction in the directions between [100] and [001], and an expansion between [001] and [1̅00]. The effect of the opening of the β angle is so large, in fact, that the directions close to (2̅03) show a slight expansion between 0 and 0.5 GPa ().

elements.content: This compound shows the shortcomings of fitting the compression of very anisotropic materials undergoing significant shear strain with conventional equations of state (such as the BM) originally derived for elastically isotropic materials undergoing isotropic compression. First, although it is obvious from the d/d 0 plot () that the [302] direction is significantly softer than the c-axis at all pressures, their refined linear moduli at room pressure are the same within their standard deviations. The difference in compressibility arises from the fact that the pressure derivative of the linear modulus of the c-axis is nearly twice (24 vs 15) that of the [302] direction. Second, the shear causes directions near (2̅03) to expand on initial compression, yielding a compression curve that cannot be adequately fit with a conventional EoS.

elements.content: Initial calculations for the structure were performed without including van der Waals interactions, and the results did not describe correctly the structure at ambient and low pressures. We conclude that the van der Waals interaction plays a crucial role in determining the structure of this compound, especially at low pressures. Therefore, in the discussion that follows, these effects have been taken into account.
elements.clean_text:
Ab Initio Calculations

Initial calculations for the structure were performed without including van der Waals interactions, and the results did not describe correctly the structure at ambient and low pressures. We conclude that the van der Waals interaction plays a crucial role in determining the structure of this compound, especially at low pressures. Therefore, in the discussion that follows, these effects have been taken into account.

elements.content: The calculated volumes are in fairly good agreement with the experimental data, being within 4%, a discrepancy expected because the simulations are effectively at 0 K whereas the experimental data was collected at 298 K. The pressure dependence of the unit-cell parameters is shown in . The agreement with experiment is again excellent. Calculation of α and β angles confirms the nonlinear behavior found by the experimental results and the independence of γ with pressure. EoS parameters () are comparable to the experimental values. These facts indicate that ab initio DFT calculations accurately describe the crystal structure of the present compound, suggesting that they can also be a powerful tool to study other physical properties.

elements.content: In addition to the structural calculations, we have therefore also determined the electronic properties. The band structure of the C10H9CuIN at ambient pressure is plotted in along the high symmetry directions within the Brillouin zone. The valence band is relatively flat, with similar dispersion along the different directions. The top of the valence band is at the Γ point of the Brillouin zone. However, there is a second maximum at Z very close in energy. The minimum of the conduction band is at the T point. Consequently, this compound is an indirect band gap material. The indirect gap Γ–T is E g = 1.02 eV, while the direct gap at Γ is only 0.07 eV smaller. To analyze the nature of the valence and conduction bands we have calculated the density of states (DoS) with a dense k-point mesh (). The upper part of the valence band is dominated by electronic states associated with the Cu d states, a minor contribution of I p states, and a small contribution of N p states. The lower part of the conduction band is composed primarily of C p states, a lower contribution of N p states, and a very small contribution of Cu d states.

elements.content: We also studied the effect of pressure on the gap energy. As pressure increases, the top of the valence band and the bottom of the conduction band shift to higher energies. Although it is well-known that DFT underestimates the gap energy values in comparison with experimental data, the pressure dependencies are in good agreement. The band gap of the present compound decreases slowly with pressure in a quadratic way: dE g/dP = −0.011 eV/GPa, and d2 E g/dP 2 = 0.001 eV/GPa2.

elements.content: The absorption spectrum recorded at ambient conditions of pressure and temperature shows a very intense band around 220 nm and, additionally, a weak broad band around 400 nm (). The assignments of the transitions have been made according to the band structure of the CuI complex obtained from DFT ab initio calculations (). These showed that the top of the valence band has a major contribution from Cu d states while the bottom of the conduction band is composed of N p and to a lesser extent C p states. Then, the 400 nm band can be related to a MLCT band, involving Cu and N ions. With respect to the high energy band (220 nm), the upper levels in the conduction band are composed mainly of C p states so in this case this is also an MLCT band but in this case with C ions as the ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Absorption Spectra

The absorption spectrum recorded at ambient conditions of pressure and temperature shows a very intense band around 220 nm and, additionally, a weak broad band around 400 nm (). The assignments of the transitions have been made according to the band structure of the CuI complex obtained from DFT ab initio calculations (). These showed that the top of the valence band has a major contribution from Cu d states while the bottom of the conduction band is composed of N p and to a lesser extent C p states. Then, the 400 nm band can be related to a MLCT band, involving Cu and N ions. With respect to the high energy band (220 nm), the upper levels in the conduction band are composed mainly of C p states so in this case this is also an MLCT band but in this case with C ions as the ligands.

elements.content: All the luminescence spectra have been obtained at RT, with an excitation wavelength of 405 nm. At ambient conditions the spectrum shows a nonsymmetric broad emission band centered approximately at 550 nm (). The spectral features of the luminescence resemble that obtained for other CuI–L complexes. As a general feature, the narrow band located around 690 nm corresponds to the R1-line of the 2E → 4A2 optical transition of Cr3+ ions in ruby, used as a pressure sensor. In order to avoid a strong overlapping of this line with the rest of the spectrum, the laser beam has been carefully focused in the sample and far from the ruby chips, but due to the high efficiency of this particular line it cannot be totally removed.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Emission Studies

All the luminescence spectra have been obtained at RT, with an excitation wavelength of 405 nm. At ambient conditions the spectrum shows a nonsymmetric broad emission band centered approximately at 550 nm (). The spectral features of the luminescence resemble that obtained for other CuI-L complexes. As a general feature, the narrow band located around 690 nm corresponds to the R1-line of the 2E → 4A2 optical transition of Cr3+ ions in ruby, used as a pressure sensor. In order to avoid a strong overlapping of this line with the rest of the spectrum, the laser beam has been carefully focused in the sample and far from the ruby chips, but due to the high efficiency of this particular line it cannot be totally removed.

elements.content: When pressure is applied up to approximately 0.8 GPa, three additional energy sub-bands emerge at 515, 647, and 712 nm denoted as pk1, pk3, and pk4, respectively (). Above 3.5 GPa another sub-band appears around 600 nm denoted as pk2. These four sub-bands show red-shifts when pressure increases, but not at the same rate. The red-shift in the two lower energy sub-bands (pk3, pk4) is approximately 11.5 nm/GPa; however, the remaining two (pk1 and pk2), around 3.0 and 7.3 nm/GPa, are in order of increasing wavelengths, respectively (see and ). The relative intensities of the four sub-bands also change, but in the range of measured pressures (0–5 GPa), the spectra shapes were reversible and reproducible upon applying and releasing pressure, with only slight differences.

elements.content: Pressure effects on the crystal are clearly reflected in the luminescence spectra, as can be observed in other systems. In the case of Cu···Cu distances and the I–Cu–I angles, these effects are important, but not so with Cu–N distances (). These allow us to infer that changes in the luminescence features are mainly related with the Cu–I cluster, more than with the quinoline ligand. On the other hand, the emergence of additional bands with increasing pressure suggests splitting in the electronic states, induced by an increase of tetrahedral distortions of the environments of the copper atoms. Different types of excited states, closely spaced in energy, may occur in these systems, including charge transfer (CT), intraligand (IL), and metal centered (MC). Thus, the observed emission may come from others which can be mechanically populated.
elements.clean_text: Pressure effects on the crystal are clearly reflected in the luminescence spectra, as can be observed in other systems. In the case of Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances and the I-Cu-I angles, these effects are important, but not so with Cu-N distances (). These allow us to infer that changes in the luminescence features are mainly related with the Cu-I cluster, more than with the quinoline ligand. On the other hand, the emergence of additional bands with increasing pressure suggests splitting in the electronic states, induced by an increase of tetrahedral distortions of the environments of the copper atoms. Different types of excited states, closely spaced in energy, may occur in these systems, including charge transfer (CT), intraligand (IL), and metal centered (MC). Thus, the observed emission may come from others which can be mechanically populated.

elements.content: The observed energy band in copper­(I) halide clusters has often been related to a triplet metal cluster centered (3MCC*) excited state involving a CuI core, and independent of the nature of the ligand. In our case, the triplet character of the transition is supported by the phosphorescent lifetimes obtained for the emission (); thus, the transitions can be described as a combination of halide-to-metal (3XMCT*), with X corresponding to iodine ions in the cluster core CuI and metal cluster centered [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] in orbital parentage. Since the spectrum at ambient conditions consists of a broad band without vibronic structure, a major contribution to the emission of the 3XMCT* transition is expected. In this regard, the [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] transition has been closely associated with the Cu···Cu distances in the core CuI cluster. Complexes with Cu···Cu distances longer than the van der Waals radii (>2.8 Å) show poor luminescence from [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu]; meanwhile, for shorter distances (<2.8 Å), the Cu···Cu bonding interaction becomes increasingly important, and most of these complexes show emissions in this interval. Therefore, the Cu···Cu distances play a key role in the photoluminescence of cuprous complexes, and reinforces the fact that more than one copper­(I) ion is involved in the excited state. In this crystal there are two relevant bond distances between the copper­(I) ions, denoted as Cu1···Cu1a and Cu1···Cu1b, with bond lengths of 2.796(4) and 3.466(3) Å, respectively. The compression behavior in the 0.0–6.45 GPa pressure range, is different for both distances. The first one decreases by ∼0.1 Å to 2.683(6) Å (4%) and the second one by >0.5 Å to 2.932(4) Å (15%), respectively (). Thus, both strong and weak metal–metal interactions are found. Moreover, the Cu···Cu distances in the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) have bonding character, which increases with the shortening of the Cu···Cu distances; consequently, the energy level tends to lowered, and a red shift of the emission band is expected. The fact of the shortening of the Cu···Cu bonds, together with the emergence of vibronic structure above 0.82 GPa, suggests an increase of the contribution of the [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] transition to the total emission. Similar structured bands can be found in the literature for coordination polymers based on copper­(I) halides and sulfur pyrimidine ligands, where the authors localized the transitions in the Cu n I m cluster. On the other hand, similar mechanochromic effects obtained upon mechanical grinding have been reported recently by Benito et al. in a cubane type [Cu4I4] complex where an additional band was observed. Considering our complex, emission bands clearly shift to red when pressure is applied, which suggests that the mechanochromism induced by pressure is a consequence of a decrease of the Cu···Cu distances.
elements.clean_text: The observed energy band in copper(I) halide clusters has often been related to a triplet metal cluster centered (3MCC*) excited state  involving a CuI core, and independent of the nature of the ligand. In our case, the triplet character of the transition is supported by the phosphorescent lifetimes obtained for the emission (); thus, the transitions can be described as a combination of halide-to-metal (3XMCT*), with X corresponding to iodine ions in the cluster core CuI and metal cluster centered [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] in orbital parentage. Since the spectrum at ambient conditions consists of a broad band without vibronic structure, a major contribution to the emission of the 3XMCT* transition is expected. In this regard, the [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] transition has been closely associated with the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in the core CuI cluster. Complexes with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances longer than the van der Waals radii (>2.8 Å) show poor luminescence from [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu]; meanwhile, for shorter distances (<2.8 Å), the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu bonding interaction becomes increasingly important, and most of these complexes show emissions in this interval. Therefore, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances play a key role in the photoluminescence of cuprous complexes, and reinforces the fact that more than one copper(I) ion is involved in the excited state. In this crystal there are two relevant bond distances between the copper(I) ions, denoted as Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu1a and Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu1b, with bond lengths of 2.796(4) and 3.466(3) Å, respectively. The compression behavior in the 0.0-6.45 GPa pressure range, is different for both distances. The first one decreases by ~0.1 Å to 2.683(6) Å (4%) and the second one by >0.5 Å to 2.932(4) Å (15%), respectively (). Thus, both strong and weak metal-metal interactions are found. Moreover, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances in the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) have bonding character, which increases with the shortening of the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances; consequently, the energy level tends to lowered, and a red shift of the emission band is expected. The fact of the shortening of the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu bonds, together with the emergence of vibronic structure above 0.82 GPa, suggests an increase of the contribution of the [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] transition to the total emission. Similar structured bands can be found in the literature for coordination polymers based on copper(I) halides and sulfur pyrimidine ligands, where the authors localized the transitions in the Cu n I m  cluster. On the other hand, similar mechanochromic effects obtained upon mechanical grinding have been reported recently by Benito et al. in a cubane type [Cu4I4] complex where an additional band was observed. Considering our complex, emission bands clearly shift to red when pressure is applied, which suggests that the mechanochromism induced by pressure is a consequence of a decrease of the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances.

elements.content: We have synthesized a new polymeric staircase copper­(I) iodine with 6-methylquinoline as the organic ligand. Its molecular structure was elucidated by X-ray diffraction. The pressure evolution of the unit-cell parameters and atomic distances with pressure suggest a soft material with an anisotropic behavior in its compressibility. The changes in Cu···Cu distances explain the red shifts observed in the luminescence spectra and their evolution from a nonsymmetric band at ambient conditions to a structured band upon applying pressure. The emission band has been associated with a triplet metal cluster centered (3MCC*) excited state involving a CuI core, with a combination of two transitions, a halide-to-metal (3XMCT*), which is dominant at ambient pressure, and a metal cluster centered [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] in orbital parentage. Ab initio simulations corroborate the experimental results on structure, and EoS describes the electronic band structure and predicts that this compound is an indirect band gap material. These features could be interesting for technological applications in the field of optical devices.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have synthesized a new polymeric staircase copper(I) iodine with 6-methylquinoline as the organic ligand. Its molecular structure was elucidated by X-ray diffraction. The pressure evolution of the unit-cell parameters and atomic distances with pressure suggest a soft material with an anisotropic behavior in its compressibility. The changes in Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances explain the red shifts observed in the luminescence spectra and their evolution from a nonsymmetric band at ambient conditions to a structured band upon applying pressure. The emission band has been associated with a triplet metal cluster centered (3MCC*) excited state involving a CuI core, with a combination of two transitions, a halide-to-metal (3XMCT*), which is dominant at ambient pressure, and a metal cluster centered [3MCC*, dCu → (s, p)Cu] in orbital parentage. Ab initio simulations corroborate the experimental results on structure, and EoS describes the electronic band structure and predicts that this compound is an indirect band gap material. These features could be interesting for technological applications in the field of optical devices.

cln_elements.content: The compound C10H9CuIN was prepared by mixing an equimolar amount of 6-methylquinoline (0.15 g, 1.05 mmol) with CuI (0.2 g, 1.05 mmol) in a saturated solution of KI in toluene (80 mL). The mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Then, the reaction mixture was filtered off, and the solid was dissolved in acetonitrile (60 mL) to give a pale yellow solution. After 2 days, single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent in high yield.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

The compound C10H9CuIN was prepared by mixing an equimolar amount of 6-methylquinoline (0.15 g, 1.05 mmol) with CuI (0.2 g, 1.05 mmol) in a saturated solution of KI in toluene (80 mL). The mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Then, the reaction mixture was filtered off, and the solid was dissolved in acetonitrile (60 mL) to give a pale yellow solution. After 2 days, single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent in high yield.

solution.name: saturated solution of KI in toluene
